definitions.definition: to stop sleeping; to make somebody stop sleeping
definitions.sensetop: wake upwake to somethingwake from somethingwake up to do somethingwake to do somethingwake somebodywake somebody up

examples.text: I always wake early in the summer.
Tom woke with a start and lifted his head.
What time do you usually wake up in the morning?
I woke up an hour earlier than I wanted to.
They woke to a clear blue sky.
I woke to the sound of heavy rain outside.
She had just woken from a deep sleep.
He woke up to find himself alone in the house.
The woman woke to see the defendant in her bedroom.
I was woken by the sound of someone moving around.
Try not to wake the baby up.
Any minute now she'd wake up to find herself at home safe in bed.
Be careful not to wake the children!
She had just woken up from a deep sleep.
She had woken even earlier than usual.

definitions.definition: to make somebody remember something or feel something again

examples.text: The incident woke memories of his past sufferings.

definitions.definition: used to tell somebody to become aware of what is really happening in a situation, especially when this is something unpleasant

wordOrigin: verb Old English (recorded only in the past tense wōc), also partly from the weak verb wacian ‘remain awake, hold a vigil’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch waken and German wachen; compare with watch.
